legalStatus.restrictions: Strict regulations under California Deferred Deposit Transaction Law (CDDTL)
legalStatus.notes: California allows payday loans but with significant consumer protections including loan amount caps, fee limits, and rollover prohibitions

regulatoryBody.name: Department of Financial Protection and Innovation
regulatoryBody.licenseType: California Deferred Deposit Transaction Law (CDDTL) License

regulations.maxLoanAmountNote: Maximum face value of check is $300; borrower receives approximately $255 after fees
regulations.maxAPRNote: California does not cap APR directly but limits fees; typical APR is 426-460% for a 2-week loan
regulations.maxFee: 15% of the face amount of the check
regulations.maxFeeNote: Maximum fee of $45 on maximum $300 loan
regulations.minTermNote: No minimum term specified; average is 16-17 days
regulations.coolingOffNote: No mandatory cooling-off period between loans
regulations.rolloverLimit: Prohibited - cannot make new loan to pay off existing loan
regulations.simultaneousLoansNote: Cannot issue new loan while borrower has existing loan, even if combined balance would not exceed $300

extendedPaymentPlan.note: Lender may offer extended payment plan; no additional fees can be charged for extension, but lender is not legally required to grant request

fees.latePaymentFee: No additional late fees beyond original fee
fees.nsfNote: Lender may charge only one bounced check fee up to $15; borrower's bank may charge additional fees
fees.collectionFees: Limited - no additional collection fees beyond original agreement
fees.otherFees: No additional fees permitted; 15% is all-inclusive

militaryProtections.description: Military Lending Act (MLA) and California AB 7 provide additional protections
militaryProtections.maxAPR: 36% MAPR for active duty military and dependents
militaryProtections.note: Due to fee restrictions, many payday lenders choose not to make loans to servicemembers and their dependents

rightToRescind.notes: California does not mandate a rescission period for payday loans

requiredDisclosures: Total cost of loan in writing
Contract must be provided in borrower's primary language
License must be posted at every location
Fee schedule must be posted at every location
prohibitedPractices: Making a new loan to pay off an existing loan (rollovers)
Issuing a new loan while borrower has an existing loan
Charging fees beyond 15% of check face value
Charging more than one bounced check fee ($15 max)
Threatening criminal prosecution for insufficient funds
Charging additional fees for payment plan or extension requests
consumerProtections.languageRequirements: Contract must be provided in borrower's primary language

collectionRules.criminalProsecution: Prohibited - cannot threaten criminal prosecution for non-payment
collectionRules.civilActions: Allowed - may pursue civil remedies only
collectionRules.garnishment: Limited - must obtain court judgment first
collectionRules.collectionPractices: Must comply with California Fair Debt Collection Practices Act

licensing.regulatoryBody: California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation (DFPI)
exemptEntities: Retail sellers offering check cashing as incidental service (fee not exceeding $2)
licensing.examinationFrequency: At least once every two years
licensing.assessmentFee: Pro rata share of DFPI administration costs (approximately $941 per location as of 2007/08)

cityPageContent.headline: California Payday Loan Regulations
cityPageContent.intro: Residents of {{city}} are protected by California's strict payday loan regulations enforced by the Department of Financial Protection and Innovation (DFPI).
keyPoints: California limits payday loans to a maximum of $300
The maximum fee is 15% of the check amount (up to $45)
Lenders cannot make a new loan to pay off an existing loan (rollovers prohibited)
You cannot have more than one payday loan at a time
If your check bounces, the lender can charge only one NSF fee of up to $15
Lenders cannot threaten criminal prosecution for non-payment
Your loan contract must be provided in your primary language
All lenders must be licensed - verify at dfpi.ca.gov
cityPageContent.complianceText: California regulates payday loans under the California Deferred Deposit Transaction Law (CDDTL), administered by the Department of Financial Protection and Innovation (DFPI). The state allows payday loans with significant consumer protections: loans are capped at $300 with a maximum fee of 15% (approximately $45). Rollovers are prohibited, meaning lenders cannot issue a new loan to pay off an existing one. California also prohibits lenders from making multiple loans to the same borrower simultaneously. All payday lenders operating in California must be licensed by the DFPI, and consumers can verify a lender's license status online or by calling 1-866-275-2677.
protectionsList: Maximum fee: 15% of check face value ($45 maximum)
Criminal prosecution: Cannot be threatened for non-payment
cityPageContent.disclaimer: IMPORTANT NOTICE: This information is provided for general educational purposes only and does not constitute legal or financial advice. Payday loans are high-cost, short-term loans with APRs that can exceed 400%. Before taking out a payday loan, consider alternatives such as personal loans, credit union loans, payment plans with creditors, or assistance from non-profit credit counseling agencies. Laws and regulations may change. For the most current information, contact the California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation at 1-866-275-2677 or visit dfpi.ca.gov. If you are experiencing financial difficulties, contact a HUD-approved housing counselor or the National Foundation for Credit Counseling at 1-800-388-2227.
cityPageContent.aprDisclosure: The typical Annual Percentage Rate (APR) for a payday loan in California is approximately 426-460% for a two-week loan. By comparison, credit cards typically have APRs between 15-30% and personal loans between 6-36%. The high APR reflects the short-term nature of payday loans and the fees charged. A $300 payday loan with a $45 fee repaid in 14 days has an APR of approximately 391%.
cityPageContent.verifyLenderText: Before obtaining a payday loan, verify the lender is licensed by the California DFPI. You can check license status at dfpi.ca.gov or call 1-866-275-2677. Unlicensed lenders may charge illegal fees, use aggressive collection tactics, and are not subject to California consumer protection laws.
